text: Who among us has not had this
moment? That kind of intimate tetat with
the nutritional label trying to discern
are you good or are you
bad? But here's the thing you probably
haven't considered. Labels are not just
labels. They evoke a set of beliefs.
That's Aaliyah
Crumb. See, Crumb had spent years
studying the placebo effect, and she
figured that food labels might work the
same way. And so, to test her idea,
Crumb
created a huge batch of
[Music]
milkshakes and then labeled it in two
very different ways.
[Music]
Then as people drank the milkshakes, she
had nurses monitor their levels of this
hormone called gorillin.
People in the medical field call it the
hunger
hormone. Basically, when you have not
eaten anything, gorillin levels in the
stomach rise, which signals to the brain
that it is time now to seek out food.

Hey, I like the rock music and I like

to I like the rock and roll music and I

but after that rise say you have a big
meal. grein levels are going to drop a
lot. And what that does is it signals to
the
mind, you've had enough here, you know,
and I'm going to start rev revving up
the metabolism so we can burn the
calories that were just ingested. But
Crumb discovered that those who believed
they were drinking the indulgent shake
responded as if their bodies had eaten
three times more. So what people
believed about their milkshake came
true. If they thought it was fattening,
they felt they'd eaten more and their
digestion was affected. Their gorillin
levels dropped three times more. So to
summarize, you may be able to change
your
metabolism with your
mind. So in theory, if you want to lose
weight, you could try eating healthy
food with an indulgent mindset. You'd
feel fuller and your metabolism would
increase. And if diet products actually
wanted to help you lose weight, they'd
advertise as fattening, not fat-ree. We
have this very simple metabolic science,
calories in, calories out. And I don't I
think that we haven't given enough
credit to the role of our beliefs in
determining our physiology, our reality.
